eu.toolchain.concurrent

Interface Stage<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type being provided by the stage
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Completable<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ConcurrentCompletable, ImmediateCancelled, ImmediateCompleted, ImmediateFailed

    public interface Stage<T>
    An interface that defines a contract with a computation that could be asynchronous.

    All methods are thread-safe guaranteeing that interactions with the stage are atomic.

    A stage has four states:

    • pending, which indicates that the stage is awaiting completion.
    • completed, which indicates that the stage has been completed.
    • failed, the stage has failed to be completed.
    • cancelled, the stage has been cancelled.

    The last three states are characterized as end states, a stage can only transition into one of these, and when in an end-state will never go into another state. If a stage is in and end state it is considered done, as is indicated by the isDone() method.

    Naming conventions of methods are the following:

    • is*, methods that query if the stage has reached a certain state.
    • when*, method that will be called once the stage reaches a certain state, but otherwise has no effect on the stage. The returned stage does not have to wait for the operation provided to end.
    • then*, method that will be called once the stage reaches a certain state, and modifies the stage when that state has been reached
    • with*, method that will be called once the stage reaches a certain state, but does modify the stage. But, the resulting stage must wait for the operation provided to the method to end.
    See Also:
    Completable

    • Method Detail

      • cancel

        boolean cancel()
        Cancel the current stage.
        Returns:
        true if the stage was cancelled by this call

      • join

        T join()
throws ExecutionException,
       InterruptedException
        Join the result of the current stage.
        Returns:
        the result of the computation
        Throws:
        ExecutionException - when the underlying computation throws an exception
        CancellationException - when the computation was cancelled
        InterruptedException - when this thread is interrupted

      • join

        T join(long timeout,
       TimeUnit unit)
throws ExecutionException,
       InterruptedException,
       TimeoutException
        Join the result of the current stage with a timeout.
        Parameters:
        timeout - timeout after which TimeoutException will be thrown.
        unit - unit of the timeout
        Returns:
        the result of the computation
        Throws:
        ExecutionException - when the underlying computation throws an exception
        CancellationException - if the computation was cancelled
        TimeoutException - when the computation does not finish within the given timeout
        InterruptedException - when this thread is interrupted

      • joinNow

        T joinNow()
   throws ExecutionException
        Join the result of the current stage, or fail if it's state is still running.
        Returns:
        the result of the computation
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the result is not available
        ExecutionException - when the underlying computation throws an exception
        CancellationException - if the computation was cancelled

      • isDone

        boolean isDone()
        Indicates if the stage is done
        Returns:
        true if the stage is completed, failed, or cancelled

      • isCompleted

        boolean isCompleted()
        Check if stage is completed.
        Returns:
        true if the stage is in a completed state, otherwise false.

      • isFailed

        boolean isFailed()
        Check if the stage was exceptionally completed.
        Returns:
        true if the stage is exceptionally completed
        See Also:
        Completable.fail(Throwable)

      • isCancelled

        boolean isCancelled()
        Check if stage is in the cancelled state.
        Returns:
        true if the stage is in a cancelled state, otherwise false.

      • cause

        Throwable cause()
        Get the cause of a failed stage.
        Returns:
        the exception that cause the stage to fail
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the stage is not in the failed state
        See Also:
        isFailed()

        the current stage

      • thenApply

        <U> Stage<U> thenApply(Function<? super T,? extends U> fn)
        Transform the value of the current stage into another type using an immediate function.

        Translates the result of a completed stage as it becomes available: 

        
   operation().thenApply(result -> result / 2);
        Type Parameters:
        U - the type of the newly applied stage
        Parameters:
        fn - transformation to use
        Returns:
        the applied stage

      • thenCompose

        <U> Stage<U> thenCompose(Function<? super T,? extends Stage<U>> fn)
        Compose the current stage with the given function.

        When the current stage has completed, calls the given function with the result of the current stage. 

        
   Stage<A> a = op1();
   Stage<B> a.thenCompose(result -> op2(result));
        Type Parameters:
        U - type of the composed stage
        Parameters:
        fn - the function to use when transforming the value
        Returns:
        the composed stage

      • thenApplyFailed

        Stage<T> thenApplyFailed(Function<? super Throwable,? extends T> fn)
        Apply a failed stage.

        This acts like a try-catch, where the provided function is the catch operation.

        Parameters:
        fn - the transformation to use
        Returns:
        the applied stage

      • thenComposeCaught

        Stage<T> thenComposeCaught(Function<? super Throwable,? extends Stage<T>> fn)
        Compose a failed stage.

        This acts like a try-catch, where the composed stage is the catch operation.

        If the intent is to re-throw after running the catch operation, use withNotComplete(java.util.function.Supplier)

        Parameters:
        fn - the transformation to use
        Returns:
        the composed stage

      • thenFail

        <U> Stage<U> thenFail(Throwable cause)
        Build a stage is failed, but waits until the current stage completes.
        Type Parameters:
        U - target type
        Parameters:
        cause - error to fail with
        Returns:
        a stage that will be failed

      • thenCancel

        <U> Stage<U> thenCancel()
        Build a stage is cancelled, but waits until the current stage completes.
        Type Parameters:
        U - target type
        Returns:
        a stage that will be cancelled

      • thenComplete

        <U> Stage<U> thenComplete(U result)
        Build a stage is completed, but waits until the current stage completes.
        Type Parameters:
        U - target type
        Parameters:
        result - result to complete with
        Returns:
        a stage that will be completed

      • withCloser

        Stage<T> withCloser(Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> complete,
                    Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> notComplete)
        Run one of the provided stages when this stage ends up in a given state.

        This is typically used to implement catch-then-rethrow style operations, like the following example: 

        
   beginTransaction().thenCompose(tx -> {
     return oper2(tx).withCloser(tx::commit, tx::rollback);
   });
        Parameters:
        complete - stage to run when this stage ends in a complete state
        notComplete - stage to run when this stage ends in a non-complete state, if the state is failed, any exception thrown in this block will suppress the original exception
        Returns:
        a new stage that depends on the supplied stage

      • withComplete

        Stage<T> withComplete(Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> supplier)
        Run the provided stage when the current stage has completed.
        Parameters:
        supplier - supplier of the stage to run
        Returns:
        a stage that depends on the current stage and the supplied stage

      • withNotComplete

        Stage<T> withNotComplete(Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> supplier)
        Run the provided stage when the current stage ends, but does not complete.
        Parameters:
        supplier - supplier of the stage to run
        Returns:
        a stage that depends on the current stage and the supplied stage
